2. The Prime Minister referred to the account issued from the Ministry of Information and appearing in the morning's newspapers of the R.A.F. attack on German naval bases on the 4th September. The statements in this account as to our losses were, he thought, misleading, and gave the impression that our losses had been less than was the fact.
The Secretary of State for Air said that he could not account for this statement, which had not been authorised by the Air Ministry.
The War Cabinet invited the Lord Privy Seal to investigate this matter, in consultation with the Minister for Information.

The First Lord of the Admiralty stated that the prisoners taken from the German submarine whose sinking is reported in Minute 3 had said that they had been ashore in Eire, and had been found to be in possession of Irish cigarettes. This information, he thought, might provide a useful lever for persuading the Eire Government to allow us the use of Berehaven as a base for Destroyers and Flying-boats. A boom was ready to be placed in position at Berehaven.
The Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs said that a representative of this country, who had been over in Dublin during the last two days, had seen Mr. de Valera and was returning that afternoon. He (the Secretary of State) undertook to pursue this matter as energetically as possible, but he was afraid that Mr. de Valera's attitude was not likely to be very helpful.

W.M. (39) 15th previous day, and it was now clear that the French Government
Conclusions, agreed with our general point of view. In view of the highly fluid
Minute 8.) nature of the present situation, he (the Secretary of State) thought

that it was urgent that the War Cabinet should consider as soon as possible what their course of action should be in the event of a German attack on Roumania, on various possible assumptions as to the attitude of Italy. It was most important that, having reached our own conclusions in this matter, we should be able at once to concert our future action with the French Government.
The Chief of the Air Staff said that this question was already under consideration by the Chiefs of Staff Committee, and he hoped that it would be possible to submit their conclusions to the War Cabinet very shortly. He would take any steps that might be necessary to ensure that the Foreign Office was kept in the closest touch with the preparation of this report.
The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs drew attention to telegram No. 215 from His Majesty's Minister, Belgrade, stating that Prince Paul did not propose to act precipitately in the matter of calling upon Bulgaria to declare her position, and that he proposed in the first place to consult the Turkish Government. The Secretary of State added that there was no indication as yet what the Turkish view was on this matter, but their reply was expected shortly.
The view was expressed that, in view of the present situation, our policy should be to encourage Yugoslavia to establish contact with Turkey. Bulgaria was, in fact, the key to the Balkans, and every effort should be made to secure that pressure was put upon her by Yugoslavia and Turkey, and if possible, by Roumania.
The War Cabinet agreed :
To give consideration to the question of the course of action to be followed in the event of a German attack upon Roumania immediately upon receipt of a report on this subject, now in course of preparation by the Chiefs of Staff Committee, with a view to reaching an agreement with the French Government on the action to be taken by the Allies.

In view of the latest appreciation of the military situation (see Minute 7 above), this question had now assumed even greater importance.
The Chief of the Imperial General Staff explained the disastrous results which, from the military point of view, would accrue to Belgium if, through refusing to permit the establishment of military contacts at the present time, she were to be invaded by Germany after that country had overrun the Netherlands.
The War Cabinet agreed :
(a) that the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs should con-
sider the despatch to Brussels of some special emissary (who must be a civilian), to impress upon the Belgian Government the gravity of the present situation and the urgency of the need for the establishment of contacts between the British and French military authorities on the one hand, and the Belgian military authorities on the other; and that, if he were to recommend the adoption of this course, he should advise the War Cabinet as to a suitable person to undertake the mission :
(b) that the Chiefs of Staff Committee should prepare, as soon
as possible, a report for the guidance of whoever should be asked to undertake the Mission:
(c) that further consideration should be given to the suggestion
to advise His Majesty The King that he should address a personal letter on this matter to the King of the Belgians.
Turkey. 14. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs stated that a
(Previous telegram dated the 15th September (No. 448) from His Majesty's Reference: Ambassador, Ankara, showed that the Turkish Government had W.M. (39) 15th decided to maintain in full their original financial demands as a Conclusions, condition of signing the proposed Treaty. This left a gap of Minute 10.) 33 millions between the last British offer and the Turkish demand.
This sum was made up of (a) a credit of 25 millions for the purchase of armaments, not necessarily to be expended in the' United Kingdom, and (b) the sum of 8 millions for unblocking Turkish credits outside the United Kingdom. In the face of these demands, it was necessary to decide whether we should agree to pay the ransom demanded by the Turkish Government, or whether we should refuse to do so, realising the risks which this course involved.

t 125 W.M. 16 (39).
In the course of the discussion which ensued, the following points were made :
(i) It was not clear whether paragraph 7 of the Ambassador's telegram meant that we should be bound to deliver in Turkey all the armaments promised before the Turkish Government's obligations became effective, or whether it meant only that we should put Turkey in a position to buy all these armaments. This ambiguity should be cleared up as soon as possible.
(ii) The line now taken by the Turkish Government definitely
suggested that they were playing for time and did not wish to commit themselves until, after the fall of Poland, it was clear whether Germany intended to attack Roumania. (On the other hand, the Roumanian Government were confident that, if they were attacked by Germany, the Turkish Government would honour their obligations and send troops to their aid.)
(iii) In the circumstances which had now arisen there would
be no advantage in increasing our financial offers in the hopes of securing the proposed Treaty with Turkey.
(iv) In view of the German threat to Roumania, and the risk
that Bulgaria might rejoin her former allies, with consequent grave threat to Turkey, it was Turkey rather than the United Kingdom whose vital interests now demanded the conclusion of the proposed Anglo-Turkish Treaty.
(v) It was essential that the attitude of the Turkish Govern-
ment should be clarified at the earliest possible moment.
(vi) Steps should be taken at once to leave the Turkish
Government in no possible doubt in regard either to the gravity of the situation or to the line which we proposed to take.
The War Cabinet agreed :
That the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs should at once address a telegram to His Majesty's Ambassador, Ankara, setting out the views of His Majesty's Government as disclosed in the discussion summarised above, and directing him to explain the position frankly to the Turkish Government, at the same time pointing out the dangers inherent in the general situation which was now developing.
Commercial 15. The War Cabinet had before them a memorandum by the
Relations with President of the Board of Trade (Paper W.P.(G.)(39) 7) on com-the Soviet mercial relations with the Soviet Union, indicating that under the Union. 10,000,000 Credit Agreement with the Soviet Government about
1 million of goods was due to be shipped during the next few weeks, consisting mainly of machinery. Export licences for these had been held up or refused; and the Soviet Union on their part had done everything to delay shipments to the United Kingdom, the most important commodity affected being softwood, for which EBgf there was an urgent demand in this country.
The President of the Board of Trade pointed out that, since the paper (W.P.(G.)(39) 7) had been circulated, it had transpired that the Admiralty had already requisitioned a large proportion of the machine tools.
The First Lord of the Admiralty said that the machine tools and machinery in question were of great importance, and he urged that none of this machinery should be allowed to go to Russia, and that timber should be obtained from other sources.
126
The Chancellor of the Exchequer admitted the gravity of the timber problem, but suggested that consideration should be given to obtaining timber from Portugal, Roumania and the United Kingdom, and possibly by requisitioning or controlling the use of timber in this country.
The Minister of Supply said that he was in the dual position of wanting timber and also wanting machinery, but on the whole his advice was that the timber was more urgently required than the machinery. The urgency was due to the fact that it would not be possible to clear the timber from the White Sea ports after the middle of October.
Some discussion ensued as to whether it would not be possible to meet the need for hutments by billeting or by some alternative building scheme.
The Prime Minister pointed out that experience in the Ottawa negotiations showed that it would not be at all easy to obtain suitable timber properly prepared from Canada. He understood from the Foreign Secretary that the best channel by which to approach the Soviet Government would be through Sir William Seeds in Moscow, and not through M. Maisky, as proposed in Paper W.P.(G.)(39) 7.
The War Cabinet agreed : (i) that the timber situation presented acute difficulty, and that it was therefore necessary to consider closely whether some effort should not be made to secure the Russian timber by the completion, or, alternatively, the partial completion, of the transactions with the Soviet Union under the ten million credit Agreement, and that this must be considered forthwith in view of the closure of the White Sea ports after mid-October: (ii) that the Foreign Secretary should ask Sir William Seeds whether he thought that an approach to the Government of the Soviet Union with the object of the completion or partial completion of the Agreement would be likely to meet with success, if it was decided to take that course:
(iii) that in the meantime the Foreign Secretary should, in
consultation with the President of the Board of Trade, prepare draft telegraphic instructions to Sir William Seeds so that these could be despatched at once if it were decided to attempt to negotiate for either the completion, or, alternatively, the partial completion, of the Agreement:
(iv) that the Minister of Supply should prepare a statement
showing the extent to which the machine tools and machinery and other equipment due to be shipped to Russia in the next few weeks were required for, and could be used for, immediate munitions production:
(v) that the Minister of Supply should prepare a statement
indicating what would be the effect on the essential building programmes of failure to acquire the Russian timber and whether and to what extent it would be possible to supply essential soft wood requirements from some other source, either at home or abroad :
(vi) that the matter should be reconsidered at once as soon as
the information asked for was available:
(vii) that, if it were decided to allow the transactions to
continue, it would be essential to take steps to ensure that the Soviet Union fulfilled their side of the bargain.
Richmond Terrace, S. W. 1, September 15, 1939.
